item.title: Presidential debate: Trump says he might 'hit Hillary harder'
item.description: After the first US presidential debate, Donald Trump complains about moderator Lester Holt and says he might be tougher on Hillary Clinton next time.

item.title: Reality Check - who was fibbing?
item.description: Fact checking the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.

item.title: Who is 'Miss Housekeeping'?
item.description: Former Miss Universe Alicia Machado claims Donald Trump, who owned the beauty contest, called her "Miss Piggy" after she gained weight.

item.title: Elon Musk outlines Mars colony vision
item.description: Entrepreneur Elon Musk outlines his vision for establishing a human colony on Mars for people that can afford a $200,000 ticket price.

item.title: Sam Allardyce: England manager leaves after one match in charge
item.description: Sam Allardyce leaves his post as England manager by mutual agreement with the FA after one match and 67 days in charge.

item.title: Porsche-driving lawyer Nathan DeSai was Houston gunman
item.description: A "disgruntled" Porsche-driving lawyer wearing Nazi emblems has been named by police as the gunman who opened fire on a Texas street, injuring nine people.

item.title: Syria conflict: Aleppo evacuation corridors needed, WHO says
item.description: The World Health Organisation wants safe routes to be set up immediately to evacuate sick and wounded Syrians from besieged parts of Aleppo.

item.title: Louisiana under-21 strippers sue for right to dance
item.description: Strippers in Louisiana are suing the US state, claiming a new law banning dancers under the age of 21 from working hinders freedom of expression.

item.title: Blast in Bronx 'drug lab' kills New York firefighter
item.description: An explosion at a drug lab inside a home in New York City kills at least one firefighter, authorities say.

item.title: First 'three person baby' born using new method
item.description: The world's first baby has been born using a new "three person" fertility technique, heralding a new era in medicine, say experts.

item.title: When Tom Hanks runs into your wedding photos
item.description: The Oscar-winning actor literally runs into a happy couple in Central Park, takes a selfie, and offers his blessing.

item.title: Sexism row grips German politics and shakes CDU
item.description: German CDU politician Jenna Behrends sparks a furore about sexism after a male colleague called her a "sweet mouse".

item.title: Theme park fined for rollercoaster crash
item.description: Alton Towers operator Merlin Attractions is fined Â£5m over the Smiler rollercoaster crash.

item.title: TB drug designed for children launched in Kenya
item.description: Kenya launches the world's first child-friendly drug, raising hopes for thousands affected by the world's deadliest infectious disease.

item.title: Saudi Arabia unveils first public sector pay cuts
item.description: Saudi Arabia unveils pay cuts for government employees for the first time, as it attempts to further rein in spending at a time of low oil prices.

item.title: Key moments from the US presidential debate
item.description: Here are the key moments from the presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.

item.title: Girl rebukes Charlotte mayor over police shootings
item.description: Girl rebukes Charlotte mayor over police shootings

item.title: Drone footage of Aleppo under siege
item.description: In one part of rebel-held Aleppo, nearly all families have left, the ones who remain face starvation.

item.title: Eels swim through flooded hospital
item.description: Heavy rain and flooding has left hospital staff chasing eels in the corridors of a hospital in Vietnam.

item.title: When Tom Hanks photobombs your wedding
item.description: The Oscar-winning actor literally runs into a happy couple in Central Park, takes a selfie, and offers his blessing.

item.title: What China made of the US debate
item.description: Chinese people who watched the debate between presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump tell the BBC who they thought won and why.

item.title: Huge blue topaz stone on loan to Natural History Museum
item.description: A blue topaz stone, thought to be the largest-ever, is to go on permanent loan to the Natural History Museum in London.

item.title: Americans watch the Clinton-Trump presidential debate
item.description: People watching in Seattle react to the Clinton-Trump presidential debate.

item.title: What did black voters make of US presidential debate?
item.description: We asked African-American voters in Harlem what they made of the US presidential debate.

item.title: Debate dissected
item.description: The first debate was arguably the key event of the US presidential race so far: and we have plenty of analysis all here in one place.

item.title: Ahmad al-Faqi al-Mahdi: The vandal of Timbuktu
item.description: Ahmad al-Faqi al-Mahdi has pleaded guilty to destroying sacred sites in Timbuktu, Mali, in the first case concerning cultural artefacts at the International Criminal Court (ICC).

item.title: Disposable women
item.description: Women in South Asia are being used and abandoned by the British Asian men who marry them. Should their treatment be classed as a form of domestic violence?

item.title: Dreams and disasters
item.description: A Japanese animated film has earned more than 10bn yen in just 28 days since its release. But what exactly is it about this film that has been drawing in the crowds?

item.title: 'People are dying'
item.description: The lucrative counterfeit drugs trade causes hundreds of thousands of deaths every year. Technology can help fight it, but are big pharma and governments doing enough?

item.title: Cheek by jowl
item.description: Colombia-based photographer Nicolas Bedoya, a co-founder of photojournalism collective Vela Colectivo, visits an area in Colombia's Antioquia province where rebels will gather to disarm following the peace agreement signed on 26 September between the Farc and the Colombian government.

item.title: Grim odyssey
item.description: Asylum seekers - mainly Afghan and Pakistani men - leave Austria for Italy, but they face bleak conditions in the city of Udine, Bethany Bell reports.

item.title: Caught in the crossfire
item.description: As Syria's government tries to recapture all of Aleppo, we ask why are children are so badly affected in the battle for the northern city.

item.title: Rob Cameron: Battle of words over 'EU army'
item.description: The idea of beefing up a EU military prompts a warning from the UK's defence secretary but reassurance from Germany and Nato.

item.title: Where the US candidates stand
item.description: This election campaign has so far been driven more by personality clashes than differences in policy. But what are the key issues and where do Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump stand?

item.title: Presidential debate 2016: US media on who won Clinton-Trump clash
item.description: The US media gives their verdict on who won the first debate, with most awarding victory to Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton.

item.title: How did moderator Lester Holt do?
item.description: NBC's Lester Holt moderated the first presidential debate after a row about how much fact-checking a moderator should do. So how did he do?

item.title: The six lives of Boko Haram's leader
item.description: Abubakar Shekau, leader of Islamist group Boko Haram has once more released a video to reject reports that he had been killed. He has been reported dead five times already.

item.title: How hawk became dove in Colombia
item.description: A profile of Juan Manuel Santos, the Colombian President who negotiated a peace deal with the Farc rebel group to put an end to more than 50 years of conflict.

item.title: Journalist Noor Tagouri to become first Muslim to appear in Playboy with a hijab
item.description: American journalist Noor Tagouri is to become the first Muslim to appear in Playboy magazine wearing a hijab.

item.title: Japanese ad showing girl turning into an eel gets pulled
item.description: A Japanese ad to promote sustainable fishing which showed a teenage girl turning into an eel is pulled after being called sexist and "perverted".

item.title: Animals in the frame
item.description: A selection of the winners and finalists in he ZSL Animal Photography Prize.

item.title: Your pictures
item.description: Each week, we publish a gallery of readers' pictures on a set theme. This week, we asked for your pictures on the theme of "dance".

item.title: Week in pictures: 17-23 September 2016
item.description: A selection of the best news photographs from around the world, taken over the past week.

item.title: Eternal flames
item.description: Indian photographer Ronny Sen is awarded the second annual Getty Images Instagram grant for his work on a coal town in India where underground fires have burned for more than 100 years.

item.title: Africa's top shots: 16-22 September 2016
item.description: A selection of the best photos from across Africa this week.

item.title: Sam Allardyce: England a laughing stock - Alan Shearer
item.description: England are the "laughing stock of world football" following Sam Allardyce's exit after just 67 days in charge, says ex-captain Alan Shearer.

item.title: Chris Froome: TUE system 'open to abuse' and athletes must take responsibility
item.description: Three-time Tour de France winner Chris Froome says the TUE system is "open to abuse" and athletes must not "push the boundaries of the rules".

item.title: Did Trump use the word âbiglyâ?
item.description: The Republican candidate appeared to use an unusual adverb in his debate against Hillary Clinton. Or did he?

item.title: Did Trump's interruptions backfire?
item.description: Jessica Lussenhop in Washington DC looks at how gender featured in the first debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton.

item.title: Five Twitter takeaways
item.description: Huge interest in the first presidential debate was reflected in a phenomenal amount of discussion online.

item.title: Who's ahead in the polls?
item.description: Follow the opinion polls as Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton go to head-to-head in the run up to the US election on 8 November.

item.title: A-Z guide to political jargon
item.description: Use our A-Z guide to find out more about some of the well-used but often misunderstood terms in US politics.
